member.name: T:Daybreak.Common.Assets.AssetReplacer
member.summary: Facilitates the dynamic and necessarily transient replacement of values.
member.remarks:
If you are intending to permanently modify an asset for the length of your mod's existence rather than in a specific or defined context, either replace the instance directly or use the Resource Pack API (TODO).
The provided APIs directly mutate the contents of an rather than, say, the stored instances in . As a result, these replacements unambiguously propagate throughout all contexts in which the asset may be needed, but they made be superseded by direct changes to values in by other mods.

member.name: T:Daybreak.Common.Assets.AssetReplacer.Handle`1
member.summary: An asset replacement handle which, when disposed, restores the replaced asset to its original value.

member.name: M:Daybreak.Common.Assets.AssetReplacer.Handle`1.Dispose
member.summary: Disposes of the handle, restoring the original asset.

member.name: M:Daybreak.Common.Assets.AssetReplacer.Replace``1(ReLogic.Content.Asset{``0},``0)
member.summary: Replaces the given asset with the new value.
member.returns: A handle to the asset replacement.

member.name: T:Daybreak.Common.Assets.DummyAssetProvider
member.summary: Manages initializing "dummy" references which wrap a base value without being associated with a repository.

member.name: M:Daybreak.Common.Assets.DummyAssetProvider.From``1(``0)
member.summary: Initializes an with value of type . This asset is disconnected from any asset repositories and content sources and is fit to be used where none are required (generally any case where the asset is just used as a strongbox for its value).
member.remarks:
This object does not need to be disposed and generally shouldn't be.
It should remain safe to do so, however.

member.name: T:Daybreak.Common.Assets.IMutableAssetProvider`1
member.summary: Provides an API to get and set the value of an asset of type .
member.remarks: This may seem somewhat redundant but facilitates additional agnosticism in the context in which an asset is provided for the API.

member.summary: The mutable asset.

member.name: E:Daybreak.Common.Features.Hooks.HookLoader.OnEarlyModLoad
member.summary: Internally used to hook into the start of mod loading; useful for injecting content into other mods.

member.name: T:Daybreak.Common.Features.Hooks.OnLoadAttribute
member.summary:
Automatically calls the decorated function on load.
If the method is instanced, it expects to be part of a parent type implementing (in which case it is called directly after ).
If the method is static, it will just be called at the end of .

member.name: P:Daybreak.Common.Features.Hooks.OnLoadAttribute.Side
member.summary: The side to load this on.

member.name: T:Daybreak.Common.Features.Hooks.OnUnloadAttribute
member.summary:
Automatically calls the decorated function on unload.
If the method is instanced, it expects to be part of a parent type implementing .
All methods will be run in reverse order at the start of
(before ).

member.name: P:Daybreak.Common.Features.Hooks.OnUnloadAttribute.Side
member.summary: The side to load this on.

member.name: T:Daybreak.Common.Features.Hooks.SubscribesToAttribute`1
member.summary:
Automatically subscribes the decorated method to the hook of type if applicable.
If this decorates an instance method, the hook will be subscribed when is called on the instance. This means instance hooks can only automatically be subscribed if the parent class is an and the instance has actually been loaded.
If this decorates a static method, the hook will be subscribed so long as the parent type is visible under and the type does not have any generic parameters (technical limitation).
member.typeparam: The hook type to subscribe the method to.

member.name: P:Daybreak.Common.Features.Hooks.SubscribesToAttribute`1.Side
member.summary: The side to load this on.

member.name: T:Daybreak.Common.Features.ModPanel.ModPanelStyle
member.summary: Facilitates the customization of s through various hooks.
member.remarks:
This style may be applied to any mod, technically, so references to your mod instance should be explicit and not assumed.
If you are using an assembly publicizer, you may instead extend , which lets you directly interface with the instead of the generic instance.

member.name: T:Daybreak.Common.Features.Rarities.IRarityTextRenderer
member.summary: A rarity which is responsible for rendering its own text in all contexts.
Renders the rarity text arbitrarily. Invoked for all contexts in which rarity text is rendered: popup text, item tooltips, and mouse hovers.
member.param: The context of the render request.

member.name: T:Daybreak.Common.Features.Rarities.ISpeciallyRenderedRarity
member.summary:
Enables special rendering of this rarity in the tooltip and pickup text displays.
Automatically applied when implemented by a . If you need to apply it to a type not defined in your assembly or in a weak-referenced scenario, see .
Renders the rarity text with special logic. Invoked for both the item's tooltip and the item's pickup text.
member.param: Whether this is rendering to the UI or in-world.

Best if the intent is essentially to create a procedural animation that may be used for all instances of the item without variation.

member.name: T:Daybreak.Common.Rendering.RenderTargetPool
member.summary: Provides a resource pool that enables reusing instances of render targets.
member.remarks:
Renting and returning buffers with a can increase performance in situations where targets are created and destroyed frequently, resulting in excessive use of VRAM.
This class is not thread-safe, and all methods and their implementations are expected to be invoked solely on the Main Thread unless explicitly specified otherwise.

member.name: P:Daybreak.Common.Rendering.RenderTargetPool.Shared
member.summary: Retrieves a shared instance.
member.remarks: The shared pool provides a default implementation of that's intended for general applicability. It assumes targets should not be manually cleared and always returns a target of the exact request descriptor and dimensions.

member.name: M:Daybreak.Common.Rendering.RenderTargetPool.Rent(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice,System.Int32,System.Int32,Daybreak.Common.Rendering.RenderTargetDescriptor)
member.summary: Retrieves a buffer that is of the exact specified dimensions and with the given render target .
member.returns: A leased target which should be disposed upon use, automatically returning the target to the pool.
member.remarks: This buffer is loaned to the caller and should be returned to the same pool via, so that it may be reused in subsequent usage of . It is not a fatal error to not return a rented buffer, but failure to do so may lead to decreased application performance, as the pool may need to create a new buffer to replace the one lost. The default implementation returns a leased target that will automatically return the pool on disposal, but different implementations or configurations are not required to do so.

member.name: M:Daybreak.Common.Rendering.RenderTargetPool.Return(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderTarget2D,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns to the pool a render target that was previously obtained via on the same .
member.param: The buffer previously obtained from to return to the pool.

If and if the pool will store the buffer to enable subsequent reuse, will clear the buffer regardless of the usage parameter so that a subsequent consumer via will not see the previous consumer's content. If or if the pool will release the buffer, the target's contents are left unchanged.
member.remarks:
This is automatically called by and generally should not be called manually without being explicitly told to do so.
Once a buffer has been returned to the pool, the caller gives up all ownership of the buffer and must not use it. The reference returned from a given call to must only be returned via once. The default may hold onto the returned buffer in order to rent it again, or it my release the returned buffer if it's determined that the pool already has enough buffers stored.

member.name: M:Daybreak.Common.Rendering.RenderTargetPool.Dispose
member.summary:
Disposes of the pool and releases any owned render targets, including ones still potentially leased.
Generally, disposal should only be performed when either the consumer has ownership over the pool and knows when all buffers have been returned, or at the very end of execution and disposal must occur (such as during mod unloading).

member.name: T:Daybreak.Common.Rendering.RenderTargetPoolExtensions
member.summary: Extension methods for that operate agnostically on any implementation.

member.name: M:Daybreak.Common.Rendering.RenderTargetPoolExtensions.RentScaled(Daybreak.Common.Rendering.RenderTargetPool,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Point,System.Single,Daybreak.Common.Rendering.RenderTargetDescriptor)
member.summary: Retrieves a buffer of size scaled by rounded up to the nearest integer value and with the given render target .
member.param: The base (unscaled) size of the target.
The scale factor of the target.
member.returns: A leased target which should be disposed upon use, automatically returning the target to the pool.

member.summary: Creates a new scope, saving the current device targets and starts rendering to the new one instead.
member.param: The device to manage targets for.

The color to clear the target to.

member.name: M:Daybreak.Common.Rendering.RenderTargetScope.Dispose
member.summary: Sets the device to use the targets that were in use before this scope was instantiated.

member.name: T:Daybreak.Common.Rendering.SpriteBatchSnapshot
member.summary:
A "snapshot" of the current state of a .
These values may be manipulated freely.
member.remarks:
This API exists for making preservation of a 's state trivial.
The act of taking a snapshot through this object's constructor is pure (that is, it has no side effects). It will not mutate the state of the being analyzed. If you intend to modify the , use the APIs provided in .
